content.question: At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math> hours, snow begins to fall. The rate at which snow accumulates is given by <math alttext="s of t equals, t raised to the three halves power, times e raised to the negative of the fraction t over 2, power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>s</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>t</mi><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></msup><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mrow></msup></mstyle></math> inches per hour. How many inches of snow accumulate during the time interval <math alttext="3 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></math> hours?

topic.text: 8.3: Using Accumulation Functions and Definite Integrals in Applied Contexts

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
